Hello Tamara!
 
💡
 
Could shifting your mindset unlock team success?
 
💡
 
In culturally diverse workplaces, balancing individual and group recognition is essential to maintaining motivation and productivity.  
When cultural values are overlooked, employees may feel disconnected and undervalued, putting team success at risk.
Let’s dive into a common challenge—and how to solve it. 
 
The Workplace Problem: Misaligned Recognition
 
A U.S.-based manager focuses on individual KPIs for their Latin American team, believing this approach drives performance. However, the team members, rooted in collectivist values, feel ignored as a group. 
 
The result?
 
Frustration grows, as team members feel their contributions to group success are overlooked. 
Motivation drops, with employees disengaging from their work. 
Collaboration weakens, as trust erodes and alignment falters. 
Ignoring cultural values creates a disconnect that impacts both morale and productivity.
 
 
The Cost of Overlooking Collectivist Values
 
Here’s what happens when cultural recognition preferences aren’t addressed: 
Employee engagement suffers, leading to lower performance. 
Team dynamics weaken, with misaligned priorities disrupting collaboration. 
Success is delayed, as motivation and trust decline. 
For leaders, balancing individual and team recognition is key to maintaining harmony and productivity.
 
 
The Solution: Balance Recognition for “We” and “Me”
 
Imagine this: 
A team where group milestones are celebrated, fostering collective pride and unity. 
Leaders who also highlight individual contributions, showing how they drive team success. 
A workplace culture that thrives on inclusion and shared accomplishments, empowering everyone. 
For example, during meetings, acknowledging individual achievements while connecting them to overall team goals builds motivation and alignment. 
 
🌎🌎🌎
 Introducing the Global Academy
 
The Global Academy equips leaders with strategies to bridge cultural recognition gaps. 
This comprehensive online course offers: 
Insights into collectivist vs. individualist values and their impact on team dynamics. 
Tools to balance individual and group recognition for maximum motivation. 
Strategies to create a workplace where everyone feels valued and engaged. 
👉
 
Click here to enroll in the Global Academy today!
 
🎉

Start 2025 with the tools to transform your team!

, for just

 (regular price $499).

Join the Global Academy here!

subject: Building Bridges: Reflecting on 2024 and Looking Ahead to 2025
body:
As we conclude 2024, the landscape of equity, diversity and inclusion (EDI) has continued to evolve, with both setbacks and strides forward
 
 
Dear colleagues,
As we conclude 2024, we have taken a moment to reflect. The landscape of equity, diversity and inclusion (EDI) has continued to evolve, with both setbacks and strides forward, and there are opportunities to make impactful progress in 2025.
In this edition: 
We summarise key developments from 2024 and look ahead to predictions for 2025.
We highlight 
Included
’s journey over 2024, with a sneak peek into what is in store for next year! And...
Reveal some immediate exciting news – we are hiring! And our audiobook is soon to be released!
Click each link for more information below. 
 
As we move into 2025, the focus on creating diverse, equitable, and inclusive environments will only intensify. While challenges remain, businesses and organisations are increasingly recognising that true inclusion is a continuous journey - one that requires constant evaluation, adaptation and, most importantly, action.
The road ahead looks promising, with innovations and shifts that are designed to create workplaces and societies where everyone has a fair opportunity to thrive.
And we stand ready to help you on your journey. Stay tuned for more updates and insights as we navigate the ever-evolving world of diversity, equity and inclusion.
Warm wishes for a wonderful festive season and a successful start to 2025.
Until next time,
Your 
Included
 Team 
2024 EDI Highlights
 
As we conclude 2024, the landscape of equity, diversity and inclusion (EDI) has continued to evolve, with both setbacks and strides forward. 
Here we cover our 2024 Highlights in EDI, including data and thoughts on workplace mental health and disability inclusion, the rise of intersectionality and global EDI expansion. We also describe some of the challenges we have faced in the industry, such as backlash against EDI programmes, diversity fatigue and underrepresentation in leadership.
Read here
 
Predictions for EDI in 2025
 
Here we look ahead to predictions for 2025, including areas such as AI and data analytics, pay equity and transparency, sustainable ESG, global EDI standardisation and many others.
Read now
 
A Year of Transformation for 
Included
 
2024 has been a landmark year for 
Included
, marked by exciting changes in leadership and board composition. In March, our Founder, Stephen Frost, transitioned from his role as CEO, passing the torch to Michelle Sequeira.
Beyond leadership changes, we have expanded our talent pool of exceptional Associates, and revisited the firms we partner with, to ensure our clients have the best service. With a renewed vision and strategy centered on societal transformation, we are excited to embark on the next chapter of our journey into 2025 and beyond.
Read now
 
We are hiring!
Following an internal role change, we have an opportunity for an experienced and passionate Head of Consulting to join our team. This client-facing role focuses on delivering impact through oversight of our EDI services, ensuring delivery quality, and deepening relationships with world-class organisations.
You will lead the Consulting function, including people management, resourcing, and project delivery, while driving business success through BD, product innovation, and strategic account leadership. Collaborating across the organisation, you’ll enhance consulting processes, inspire thought leadership, and deliver exceptional results for clients globally.
Applications will be going live within the next 48 hours. Please keep an eye on our website and LinkedIn page for further information. 
Our website
 
 
The Key to Inclusion Audiobook 
We are delighted to share that our book, 
The Key to Inclusion
, is soon to be available in audio format. This book, written in 2022, is a practical guide to Diversity, Equity and Belonging for You, Your Team and Your Organisation. Recognising the importance of diversity, belonging and equity is not enough and this book has the practical guidance needed to think differently and make true inclusion a reality.
To mark this exciting moment, we are offering you the chance of winning a free audio book code. Please visit the below link for further information. Good Luck!
 
Find out more
 
 
How inclusive are your company’s end-of-year parties?
 
From Christmas to Hanukkah to Kwanzaa, many individuals and organisations will take the opportunity to celebrate the end of the year with an event or gathering. You may have scheduled your organisation’s end of year party, but how can you ensure all your colleagues are able to participate and enjoy themselves?

Hello Tamara!
 
💡 
Whose goals are more important: Those of the individual or those of the team? 
💡
 
In global teams, the goals of the individual and the goals of the team don’t always align, leading to misunderstandings and frustration.  
In fact, when employees prioritize different goals—personal performance vs. team success—these differences often create tension and derail collaboration.  
U.S. employees may, for example, focus their efforts on personal performance, aiming to excel individually. Meanwhile, their Korean colleagues emphasize team success, prioritizing harmony and collective achievement. 
The result?
 
Friction builds, as each side feels the other isn’t contributing effectively. 
Trust erodes, leading to misunderstandings about values and priorities. 
Productivity declines, as the team struggles to align on shared goals. 
 
When leaders fail to address these clashes, morale drops, and progress stalls.
Now, imagine this: 
A team where personal performance and group achievements are equally valued and rewarded. 
Leaders who align priorities by setting group KPIs alongside individual metrics. 
A workplace culture that leverages the strengths of both perspectives, driving innovation and collaboration. 
You can unlock your team’s full potential by creating systems that honor individual contributions and team success.
 
 
🌎🌎🌎
 Introducing the Global Academy
 
Ready to take the lead? Join the 
Global Academy
 
🌍
 and empower your team to thrive through alignment and understanding. 
The
 Global Academy
 equips leaders with actionable strategies to bridge the gap between individualism and collectivism. This online course provides: 
Insights into balancing cultural values in team dynamics. 
Tools to align individual and group priorities for maximum engagement. 
Strategies to build a workplace that thrives on cultural diversity and collaboration.
 
👉 
Click here to enroll in the Global Academy today!
 
🎉
 
Start the New Year Strong
 
Set your team up for success in 2024! 
💸
 Enroll by 
December 31, 2024
, for just 
$199
 (normally $499). 
⏳
 Don’t wait! Learn how to foster teamwork that aligns individual and collective goals today.
 
👉
 
Join the Global Academy here!
 
Bye for now! 
P.S. Have questions? Just reply to this email, and I’ll be happy to help! 
  
 
Luiza

subject: [NEW] Planning to Thrive in 2025
body:
I was recently conducting a coaching session with a client who has been in the middle of an extensive period of turmoil and uncertainty...
 
 
 
I was recently conducting a coaching session with a client who has been in the middle of an extensive period of turmoil and uncertainty - financial insecurity, caring for a parent with a long-term illness, meeting demands of global projects, and more. When she looked at it all together, it made her feel despondent. She was exhausted, listless, unable to focus. 
My client and I decided to spend our conversation exploring how to move out of this survival mode in which she had been living for so long, so we came up with a theme of “How to Thrive in 2025.” As we explored what rich lessons she learned this last year, her view of her “survival” mode as a weight was lifted, and she was able to honor all that her body and spirit allowed her to do during this season of immense challenges. As we discussed the future that she wants to create, she was able to think more clearly about what demands she has placed on herself that do not serve her, and where she is worrying about things she has no control over.
Thriving means embracing a season of vigorous growth. We cannot grow and flourish if our energy is diluted.  When we experience intense periods of pressure, frustration, and crisis, our brains and bodies are thrown into a chronic state of stress. It increases feelings of isolation, burnout, helplessness, and demoralization, which then further fuel the stress. It’s the old adage of the snake eating its own head. 
There will continue to be pressures, frustrations, and crises that inundate our lives at the micro and macro levels in the year to come. For those of us involved in DEI and justice work, it is a deeply disturbing time as we watch leaders axe initiatives and looming government policies rolling back basic human and civil rights. It’s easy to fall into the trap of exaggerating the negative stories, yet I have found an equal number of examples of leaders reinforcing their DEI commitments and persisting in their efforts. 
In order to create the conditions for vigorous growth, we need to both practice individual wellbeing and to sustain community. This means more than superficial ideas of self-care or social activities. That’s like watering the pot once and expecting the plant to rapidly grow, instead of fertilizing the soil and placing the pot in the appropriate environment in terms of light, moisture, and heat. 
Take the final weeks of 2024 to consider what it means for you to thrive in 2025.
How can you honor yourself for your capacity to survive all the hard days you’ve experienced so far?
How can you shift to a focus on thriving in the months to come? 
Whose support do you need to accept?
What might you let go of to free yourself to thrive?
What will be possible for you if you make these changes?
 
Maria Morukian
Founder and Chief Executive Officer
MSM Global Consulting
MSM GLOBAL UPDATES
 
Maria Morukian Featured at the Global HR Forum in Seoul
Last month, Maria Morukian represented MSM Global Consulting at the prestigious Global HR Forum 2024 in Seoul, South Korea. Presenting to an audience of global leaders and HR professionals, Maria led a session titled "DEIB: Tapping into the Power of Thriving Organizations." The session explored the essential role of diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging (DEIB) in fostering creativity, innovation, and sustained organizational success. Attendees gained actionable insights into building inclusive workplaces that empower employees and drive results.
The Global HR Forum is a premier platform for addressing global talent development challenges, bringing together thought leaders from government, business, and education sectors. This year’s event welcomed over 6,100 participants to share best practices and insights on nurturing human resources for a rapidly changing future.
Fostering Intercultural Collaboration in Global Health
MSM Global Consulting recently completed a transformative Intercultural Competence Cohort Program for a client in the global health sector. This three-part series included: 
Exploring a Continuum for Intercultural Development, guiding participants to identify stages of intercultural competence and strategies for growth​.
Navigating Intercultural Conflict, with discussions on culturally responsive techniques for healthy conflict resolution​.
Building Effective Intercultural Teams, focusing on trust, psychological safety, and cultural considerations for team dynamics​.
Participants developed skills to enhance collaboration and create high-performing, culturally diverse teams. If your organization is interested in similar programs, reach out to us at info@msmglobalconsulting.com. 
Culture Stew
Episode: Protecting Your Peace and Sustaining Momentum for Social Change
November 20, 2024
In this compelling episode, Maria explores how social justice leaders can safeguard their well-being while driving change. She introduces strategies for self-care, community care, and fostering resilience in the face of systemic challenges. Dive into actionable insights to stay grounded and impactful. 
Listen now.
Episode: Holding Up the Mirror—Reimagining DEI and Systemic Change with Wendy Moomaw
 
December 11, 2024
Join Maria in conversation with Wendy Moomaw as they delve into the transformative potential of DEI. This episode challenges traditional narratives and explores innovative approaches to creating systemic change. Wendy shares her journey, insights, and strategies for advancing equity and inclusion.
 Tune in here
.
 
MSM GLOBAL GALLERY
Here you can find curated content of current DEI issues and events for your further exploration.
 
Building leadership resilience: The CORE framework 
This resource from the Center for Creative Leadership introduces the CORE framework, designed to help leaders build resilience amidst uncertainty and change. CORE—standing for Composure, Optimism, Resilience, and Efficacy—offers actionable insights and practices to strengthen personal and organizational adaptability. It equips leaders with tools to remain composed under pressure, maintain optimism, recover from setbacks, and lead with confidence and purpose.
In times of rapid change and uncertainty, resilience is a critical skill for leaders striving to inspire teams and maintain organizational momentum. The CORE framework provides a structured, evidence-based approach to developing resilience, helping leaders not only navigate challenges but also seize opportunities to grow stronger and more effectively. It’s particularly valuable for DEI practitioners and organizational leaders aiming to sustain long-term progress despite systemic and external pressures.
Access the resource here
!
The Four Pivots: Reimagining Justice, Reimagining Ourselves by 
Shawn Ginwright 
- We can’t stop recommending this book! 
In The Four Pivots, Shawn Ginwright challenges traditional approaches to social justice work by calling for a deeper focus on healing and transformation. With four key pivots—Awareness, Connection, Vision, and Presence—Ginwright provides a powerful framework for shifting from reactive problem-solving to proactive envisioning of a better world. The book blends personal reflection, actionable strategies, and hope-filled narratives to inspire a more human-centered approach to equity and systemic change. 
We're waiting for you! 
Would you like to be a guest on the Culture Stew Podcast? 
Do you have a publication we can share on our newsletter or on our social media accounts? 
 
Contact us at 
CultureStew
@MSMGlobalConsulting.com
 TODAY! 
CONTENT FOR YOUR DOWN TIME
Here are some recommended articles and books for your down time.
 
"Mood Booster" Playlist
Music has an incredible ability to shift our mood, spark joy, and create an environment where we can thrive. This curated Mood Booster Playlist features uplifting tracks by diverse artists, blending soulful rhythms, energizing beats, and inspiring lyrics. Whether with this playlist, or a playlist that you make yourself, music can reframe your environment. 
Why this matters:
Research consistently shows that music can significantly impact mental health, productivity, and emotional well-being. A study published in Frontiers in Psychology highlights how listening to music not only reduces stress but also enhances mood and fosters creativity by stimulating the brain's reward centers. Incorporating music into your daily routine can act as a powerful tool for self-care and cultivating a thriving mindset.
For more on the science of music and its impact, check out the article” 
How Music Resonates in the Brain | Harvard Medicine Magazine
”.
Listen to this playlist on Spotify
 or create your own!
 
Visioning for 2025 
Vision boards are powerful tools for manifesting goals and creating a roadmap to the life you want to lead. By combining imagery, words, and creativity, they provide a visual representation of your aspirations, helping to clarify your goals and align your actions with your dreams. Engaging in this process encourages intentionality, focus, and self-reflection, which are essential for thriving in a complex, goal-oriented world.
Why Vision Boards Help Us Thrive:
Focus
: Vision boards help you prioritize what truly matters to you.
Motivation
: Seeing your goals visually represented can inspire daily action and persistence.
Positivity
: Crafting a vision board encourages a mindset shift from scarcity to abundance, emphasizing possibilities rather than limitations.
Connection
: They create an opportunity to identify how personal goals align with broader values and community goals.
Use a tool like 
Canva 
for an alternative to a paper vision board! 
Here is a helpful guide to get you started.
 
 
 
About MSM Global
We specialize in organizational culture change by empowering organizations to achieve greater success through embracing equity, diversity and inclusivity. We provide a holistic approach to organizational development, team capacity building, and leadership development. Let us know what would be helpful for you in this newsletter.
Connect with us!
Email:
 info@msmglobalconsulting.com
Call: 
(202) 827-6597

subject: Bringing an Intersectional Lens to Domestic Violence Awareness and Prevention
body:

When she looked at it all together, it made her feel despondent. She was exhausted, listless, unable to focus.

We cannot grow and flourish if our energy is diluted.  When we experience intense periods of pressure, frustration, and crisis, our brains and bodies are thrown into a chronic state of stress. It increases feelings of isolation, burnout, helplessness, and demoralization, which then further fuel the stress. It’s the old adage of the snake eating its own head.

Focus
: Vision boards help you prioritize what truly matters to you.
Motivation
: Seeing your goals visually represented can inspire daily action and persistence.
Positivity
: Crafting a vision board encourages a mindset shift from scarcity to abundance, emphasizing possibilities rather than limitations.
Connection
: They create an opportunity to identify how personal goals align with broader values and community goals.
Use a tool like 
Canva 
for an alternative to a paper vision board! 
Here is a helpful guide to get you started.

We specialize in organizational culture change by empowering organizations to achieve greater success through embracing equity, diversity and inclusivity. Hello Tamara!
💡
 
Is standing too close ruining your business deals?
 
💡
 
In global workplaces, personal space norms vary widely, and these subtle differences can lead to misunderstandings. What feels like trust-building in one culture might feel intrusive in another. Let’s explore how these mixed signals can impact your relationships—and how to avoid them. 
 
The Workplace Problem: When Personal Space Sends the Wrong Signal
 
A U.S. executive (used to valuing personal space) steps back as their Saudi Arabian counterpart moves closer during a conversation. 
The result?
 
Discomfort grows, as both parties misinterpret the other’s intentions. 
Relationships are strained, making collaboration more challenging. 
Opportunities are missed, as trust fails to form. 
When cultural norms for personal space aren’t understood, even minor interactions can derail progress. 
 
The Cost of Ignoring Personal Space Norms
 
Here’s what happens when these differences aren’t addressed: 
Tension rises, as team members feel uneasy during interactions. 
Trust erodes, making it harder to build strong relationships. 
Collaboration falters, with cultural misunderstandings creating unnecessary barriers. 
For leaders, understanding the power of personal space is key to fostering rapport and connection. 
 
The Solution: Mastering the Space Between
 
Imagine this: 
Teams that understand cultural norms for personal space and foster mutual respect and trust. 
Leaders who navigate these differences with confidence and build stronger connections. 
A workplace where cultural understanding removes barriers to collaboration and success. 
In high-contact cultures like Saudi Arabia, closeness signifies trust, while in low-contact cultures like the U.S., distance conveys respect. Learning to balance these norms ensures smoother interactions. 
 
🌎🌎🌎
 Introducing the Global Academy
 
The Global Academy provides the tools your team needs to decode nonverbal behaviors like personal space. 
This comprehensive online course offers: 
Insights into personal space norms across cultures and their impact. 
Strategies to foster rapport and trust in diverse teams. 
Tools to create an environment where nonverbal cues enhance relationships.

secure your spot today!

Hello Tamara!
 
💡
 
How does your team view deadlines: rigid or flexible?
 
💡
 
In multicultural workplaces, attitudes toward time differ widely, often creating misunderstandings. While some cultures view deadlines as non-negotiable, others see them as flexible guidelines. These differences can cause frustration, erode trust, and delay projects if not addressed. 
 
The Workplace Problem: Conflicting Time Perspectives
 
A U.S. manager expects tasks to follow a strict schedule, reflecting their monochronic culture, which values punctuality and structure. 
Their Brazilian counterpart, from a polychronic culture, prioritizes relationships and sees deadlines as adaptable. When the deadline is missed, the manager feels disrespected, while the counterpart feels misunderstood. 
 
The result?
 
Frustration builds, damaging the working relationship. 
Projects are delayed, as expectations are misaligned. 
Trust erodes, making collaboration increasingly difficult. 
Misaligned cultural attitudes toward time can derail even the best-laid plans. For global teams, understanding cultural nuances around time is critical to success. 
 
The Solution: A Collaborative Approach
 
Imagine this: 
Teams that acknowledge and respect cultural attitudes toward time and preventing conflicts. 
Leaders who build buffer time into schedules and create room for flexibility while meeting goals. 
A workplace where trust and collaboration thrive, with realistic expectations for everyone. 
By understanding monochronic and polychronic perspectives, you can bridge cultural gaps and drive better outcomes. 
 
🌎🌎🌎
 Introducing the Global Academy
 
The Global Academy equips leaders with actionable strategies to navigate cultural differences around time. 
This online course offers: 
Insights into monochronic vs. polychronic cultures and their workplace impact. 
Tools to create flexible yet structured schedules that accommodate diverse perspectives. 
Strategies to foster trust and efficiency in global teams.

Hello Tamara!
💡
 
What’s your body saying that your mouth isn’t? 
💡
 
In global workplaces, nonverbal communication speaks volumes—but its meaning varies across cultures. Misunderstanding body language can create discomfort and damage trust, even when intentions are good. Let’s explore how these subtle signals can impact your team. 
The Workplace Problem: Nonverbal Misunderstanding
 
A U.S. manager gives feedback to a Thai team member, maintaining eye contact to convey confidence. But for the Thai employee, prolonged eye contact feels intense and disrespectful, leading to discomfort and disengagement. 
The result?
 
Trust breaks down, as employees feel misunderstood and uncomfortable. 
Collaboration suffers, with misinterpreted cues creating barriers. 
Team morale dips, as small signals lead to outsized effects on relationships and productivity. 
When nonverbal cues are misaligned, they can silently derail workplace harmony. 
 
The Cost of Ignoring Nonverbal Communication 
Here’s what happens when cultural norms for body language go unaddressed: 
Discomfort spreads, creating distance between team members. 
Productivity declines, as trust and connection weaken. 
Collaboration stalls, with misunderstandings undermining team dynamics. 
These small but impactful issues can affect morale and organizational success. 
 
The Solution: Master the Silent Language 
Imagine this: 
Teams that understand and respect cultural norms for gestures, posture, and eye contact. 
Leaders who foster trust and connection by aligning their body language with cultural expectations. 
A workplace where nonverbal communication enhances, rather than hinders, collaboration. 
For example, in Thailand, avoiding prolonged eye contact with authority figures conveys respect—a simple adjustment that fosters harmony and trust. 
 
🌎
🌎
🌎

Hello Tamara!
💡
 
Ever wonder why your global teams aren’t ‘getting it’?
 
💡
In diverse workplaces, communication styles can clash, leading to frustration and misunderstandings. When expectations aren’t aligned, even the most capable teams struggle to collaborate effectively. Let’s explore how this happens—and how you can fix it. 
 
The Workplace Problem: Presentation Mismatch
 
An Indian team member presents a proposal to their U.A.-American colleagues, using storytelling and metaphors to build context. Meanwhile, the Americans—expecting concise, data-driven slides—tune out. 
The result? 
Frustration builds, with both sides feeling misunderstood. 
Trust erodes, as perceptions of competence come into question. 
Collaboration breaks down, with missed opportunities and stalled progress. 
Misaligned communication preferences don’t just create friction—they derail productivity.
 
 
The Cost of Miscommunication
 
When organizations fail to address these gaps: 
Respect and trust within teams erode, leading to disengagement. 
Projects miss deadlines, as collaboration becomes inefficient. 
Opportunities are lost, as innovative ideas get overlooked. 
Without clear strategies, these issues can impact both morale and business outcomes.
 
 
The Solution: Balance Communication Styles
 
Imagine this: 
Teams that combine storytelling with data-driven insights for presentations that engage everyone. 
Employees who clarify expectations before meetings, fostering alignment and understanding. 
A workplace where collaboration thrives, leveraging diverse communication styles to drive success. 
By balancing communication preferences, you can turn misunderstandings into opportunities for connection.

Hello Tamara!
💡
 
Is ‘I’ll do my best’ a polite no—or an actual maybe? 
💡
 
In today’s global workplace, the degree of directness varies significantly across cultures. Misinterpreting this difference can lead to missed opportunities, strained relationships, and stalled progress. Let’s dive into how this plays out—and how you can address it. 
 
The Workplace Problem: Mixed Signals in Team Dynamics
 
A U.S. manager assigns a critical task to a Mexican team member. The employee replies, “I’ll do my best.” The manager assumes full commitment to the task, but the employee sees this phrase as an honest attempt, not a guarantee. 
The outcome? 
The task is only partially completed, leaving the manager frustrated. 
The employee feels unappreciated. 
 
The Cost of Misaligned Expectations
 
When communication styles aren’t culturally attuned, the effects can be significant: 
Projects falter when assumptions go unchecked. 
Team relationships weaken as trust and morale decline. 
Productivity suffers, with misunderstandings slowing progress. 
These gaps can jeopardize team cohesion and results. 
 
The Solution: Build Bridges with Adaptive Communication
 
Picture this: 
Managers and employees who adapt their communication to reflect shared understanding and intent. 
Teams that celebrate cultural differences, turning them into strengths rather than barriers. 
Outcomes that excel because everyone speaks the same "language" of clarity and respect. 
Simple strategies—like asking follow-up questions such as, 
“If this timeline does not work for you, what is a better alternative?”
 or clarifying expectations early—can transform interactions into productive exchanges. 
 
Introducing The Global Academy
 
The Global Academy equips leaders with tools to master tone and directness across cultures. 
This online course provides: 
Step-by-step strategies to navigate cultural nuances in communication. 
Tools to foster clear, productive dialogue with clients and teams. 
Insights to build a workplace where cultural differences enhance collaboration.

 at checkout.

🌟

Hello Tamara!
💡
 
What happens when ‘yes’ doesn’t actually mean yes? 
💡
In global teams, words don’t always mean the same thing across cultures and misunderstandings can derail critical projects, damage trust, and leave employees feeling frustrated and disconnected. 
 
Imagine the Following Situation
A U.S.-based manager asks a Japanese team member if they can meet a deadline. The team member nods and says, “Yes.” The manager interprets this as an agreement, but when the deadline arrives, the task isn’t done. 
Why?
In many cultures, “yes” signals acknowledgment, not agreement. Without clarifying intent, communication breaks down, creating confusion on both sides. 
 
The Cost of Miscommunication
 
Here’s what happens when cultural differences in language go unaddressed: 
Trust erodes, as managers feel employees are unreliable, and employees feel misunderstood. 
Team morale dips, as frustration mounts over preventable conflicts. 
Time and resources are wasted, derailing projects and hurting organizational success. 
For leaders, navigating these differences without the right tools can feel like an uphill battle. 
 
Small Shifts, Big Impact
 
Imagine this: 
A workplace with no miscommunication or misunderstandings. 
Leaders skilled enough to ask clarifying questions like: 
“Does this mean you agree or that you understand?”
 
Teams that communicate with clarity and trust, driving greater collaboration and success. 
By making small adjustments to communication practices, you can bridge even the largest cultural gaps. 
 
🌍
 Introducing The Global Academy
 
The Global Academy is your guide to mastering cross-cultural communication. 
This comprehensive online course offers: 
Actionable strategies to navigate cultural differences in language and meaning. 
Tools to foster trust and alignment across global teams. 
Insights to build a culture of clear, inclusive communication.

subject: 🤔 Unconscious Bias: 2 FAQs You Need to Know
body:
Continue reading to learn the answer to two frequently asked questions about bias. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Tamara!
As we continue our journey toward a more inclusive workplace, it's essential to address some common questions about 
unconscious bias
. 
Below, I’ve answered two of my frequently asked questions to help deepen your understanding of how unconscious bias impacts our decision-making—and what we can do about it. 
 
1. Can unconscious bias be completely eliminated?
No, unconscious bias can’t be fully eliminated—it’s a natural part of how our brains process information. However, we can 
reduce
 its influence through awareness and intentional strategies. By recognizing our biases, we can take steps to prevent them from influencing critical decisions, such as hiring, promotions, or performance evaluations. 
Actionable Tip
:
 Implement bias awareness training and use structured, standardized criteria for decision-making to mitigate the impact of bias. 
 
2. How can we measure the impact of unconscious bias in the workplace?
While unconscious bias itself is hard to measure, its 
effects
 are often visible in workplace patterns.  
Look for discrepancies in hiring, promotions, performance ratings, or employee retention rates across different demographics.  
A lack of diversity in leadership roles or disproportionate turnover rates may signal the presence of unconscious bias in your processes. 
Actionable Tip
:
 Regularly review your data on recruitment, promotions, and performance reviews. Use these insights to adjust policies and ensure fairness. 
 
📢
 
📢
📢

Mastering Cultural Differences is excited to bring you an exclusive email series this December focused on 
"Cultural Differences Impacting the Workplace."
 
🌍💼
 Discover actionable insights on how cultural competence can transform team dynamics, enhance collaboration, and boost innovation in diverse work environments. 
Stay tuned! 
📩
 #CulturalCompetence #DEI 
Bye for now!
 
Luiza

subject: 🌟 This Week’s DEI+ Spotlight: Tackling Maternal Bias in the Workplace 🌟
body:
Continue reading to understand the impact of maternal bias in the workplace. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Dear Tamara,
I’d like to share a personal story with you that highlights a very real issue: 
maternal bias in the workplace.
Several years ago, I had the chance to work on a significant project in Ukraine. It was an exciting opportunity to broaden my skills and make a meaningful impact.  
But here’s the catch: I had to 
fight
 for that assignment.  
The reason I wasn’t offered the opportunity initially was simple—
I had young children
 at the time. 
The assumption? That, as a mother, I wouldn’t be interested in such a demanding project or travel. This false narrative—that mothers are less committed to their careers—undermines the professional growth of countless women.  
In fact, maternal bias remains a persistent barrier for women, subtly influencing hiring, promotions, and perceptions of competence. 
In this week’s 
DEI+ newsletter
, we explore: 
The hidden impacts of maternal bias on workplace culture. 
Real-world examples of how organizations are addressing this challenge. 
Practical strategies to foster equity for parents in your team. 
 
📌📌 
CLICK HERE TO ACCESS THE BLOG
 
Let’s work towards a workplace where all employees—parents included—feel supported and valued.
 
Together, we can make belonging a reality for everyone. 
Bye for now!
Luiza

subject: 🚨 The Hidden Impact of Bias: Are You Missing Out on Talent?
body:
Continue reading to learn the impact og bias in decision making. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Tamara!
Let’s take a moment to consider the impact of bias in decision-making—something that often goes unnoticed, but can profoundly affect who gets hired, promoted, or recognized in the workplace.
Here are two powerful examples:
 
In one study, simply replacing a woman’s name with a man’s name on a resume 
increased the likelihood of being hired by more than 60%
—even though the qualifications remained the same. 
Major orchestras experienced a similar shift. When they introduced blind auditions, where gender was removed from the equation, 
the chances of women advancing past the first round improved by 50%
. 
These examples highlight what’s known as 
performance bias
—the tendency to unintentionally undervalue the contributions of certain groups based on preconceived notions.  
This bias leads to missed opportunities, lower performance ratings, and slower career progression for individuals, particularly women and underrepresented groups. And the impact can be enormous. 
The challenge is that without clearly defined, objective criteria for hiring, promotion, or performance reviews, decisions often default to “gut feelings,” which can be influenced by unconscious biases. 
Your Action Step
: For your next opening, start by establishing clear, objective hiring and review criteria that are consistently applied across your organization. These criteria help ensure decisions are based on performance and merit—not influenced by biases or assumptions. 
When everyone operates from the same standards, you reduce the risk of missing out on top talent and ensure that opportunities are given fairly.
Bye for now!
 
 
Luiza
___________________________________
 
Luiza Dreasher, President and CEO (she/her/hers)
Mastering Cultural Differences 
I work with leaders who want to create a work environment where all employees feel valued and want to stay.

subject: 🎥 Must-Watch: The Danger of a Single Story – A Powerful Lesson for Inclusive Workplaces
body:
Watch this short, compelling video on the dangers of a single story. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Tamara!
I want to share with you a TED Talk that profoundly resonates with the work we do in fostering diverse and inclusive environments: 
Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie’s "The Danger of a Single Story."
In this compelling talk, Adichie explores how limiting our understanding of people to a “single story”—a one-dimensional narrative—can perpetuate stereotypes and unconscious biases.
Her insights are a powerful reminder that in the workplace, it’s easy to view colleagues or clients through narrow lenses, missing the richness and complexity of their experiences and talents. 
By challenging the "single story," we open doors to deeper understanding, better collaboration, and truly inclusive workplace cultures.  
I encourage you to watch this and reflect on how embracing diverse perspectives can transform your organization. 
CLICK HERE TO WATCH
.
Your Action Step
: After watching the talk, consider initiating conversations within your teams about how “single stories” might be shaping decisions, and explore ways to create more inclusive narratives for everyone. 
Bye for now!
 
Luiza

Hello Tamara!
Are you ready to foster a workplace where every team member feels truly valued and supported? Join us for an upcoming webinar hosted by SCORE-Los Angeles, where I’ll be leading a session on how you can create an environment of inclusivity and high performance: 
📌
 The DEI Advantage: Dispelling Misconceptions& Achieving Organizational Success
 
In this session, we’ll uncover the truth behind DEI, equipping you with actionable strategies to strengthen team collaboration and create a culture of unity and respect. Here’s what you can look forward to: 
·
       
Gain a deeper understanding
 of diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI), and why it’s crucial for creating thriving workplaces. 
·
       
Explore the four distinct layers of diversity
 and learn how they shape individual experiences and organizational dynamics. 
·
       
Understand why DEI is a must-have
 for organizations of every size, and how it directly impacts innovation, productivity, and retention. 
·
       
Uncover the roots of resistance to DEI
 and develop practical strategies to overcome pushbacks and foster inclusivity. 
·
       
Learn what DEI high performers do 
and the key practices that set them apart in creating inclusive environments. 
Plus, all attendees will receive a 
free DEI Assessment
 and exclusive access to a video and facilitator’s guide on addressing DEI resistance. 
This isn’t just another webinar—it’s an opportunity to lead meaningful change and create a workplace where everyone belongs. Don’t miss the chance to take actionable steps toward a stronger, more connected organization! 
👉

Luiza

subject: 🌟 Best Practices for Addressing Unconscious Bias in Your Workplace 🌟
body:
Learn best practices for addressing unconscious bias in the workplace. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Tamara!
Earlier in the week, you learned about Sarah. Let’s revisit her story.  
She’s an outstanding employee but repeatedly gets passed over for leadership opportunities. Why? Unconscious bias.  
Despite her strong performance, decisions are subtly influenced by bias, leading to her being overlooked in favor of colleagues who seem more “familiar” or "likable." 
Sarah’s not alone. Many employees experience this silent bias, which can damage morale and productivity over time. These biases are rarely intentional but can have profound effects if not addressed. 
The good news? There are practical steps to create a fairer, more inclusive workplace. Here’s what the best organizations are doing to tackle unconscious bias: 
Implement Bias Awareness Training
: Equip employees with the skills to recognize and mitigate their own biases. 
Diversify Decision-Making Panels
: Include a variety of perspectives in hiring, promotion, and leadership decisions. 
Standardize Evaluation Criteria
: Use clear, objective benchmarks for performance reviews and promotions to reduce subjectivity. 
Encourage Inclusive Leadership
: Train leaders to actively support underrepresented groups and challenge their assumptions. 
By integrating these best practices, organizations move closer to an environment where employees like Sarah can thrive without barriers. It’s not just about awareness—it’s about creating actionable, lasting change. 
Your Action Step
: Begin with bias awareness training and follow it up with concrete policies like standardized evaluations to ensure consistent, fair decision-making. 
 
Bye for now! 
Luiza

Luiza Dreasher, President and CEO (she/her/hers)

subject: Staying TRU to Purpose: How to Protect Your Peace and Sustain Momentum for Social Change
body:
The results of this week’s presidential election have further magnified the immense ideological divide in our country,
 
 
 
The results of this week’s presidential election have further magnified the immense ideological divide in our country, and illustrate the deeply rooted systems that perpetuate othering and oppression.
 To be sure, regardless of who is in the White House, those systems would still exist and the work to overcome them would continue. The road ahead of us will doubtless have more obstacles, and be more perilous. But America hasn’t changed since Tuesday. It’s the same flawed, contradictory, messy, frustrating place it was before the ballots were counted. 
As I have shared in my previous writing, my dad was a high school history teacher. He taught me the importance of looking at patterns throughout history to put the present day in context. We have experienced times like this before, where our institutions did little or nothing to address injustice, or actively worked to oppress. The playbook of inequity  is there in front of our faces. It hasn’t changed much.
So where do we go from here?
At our October Ember gathering, we introduced the concept of being TRU. TRU stands for:
TRANSCENDING the Static
REDEFINING the concept of Care
UNLEASHING our wild Imagination
Transcend the Static.
This week I am trying to distance myself from the noise, and to find quiet, so I can reconnect with my purpose. There is so much noise around us right now. It’s hard to concentrate and even process what we’re experiencing in all this noise. I’m reminded of the NASA astronauts’ experience when they first saw the Earth from orbit. They describe this deeply transcendent experience where they were awestruck by the absolute beauty of our planet and the gift of life it has bestowed upon us, and they grieved humanity’s inability to honor that gift, and the ongoing social injustice, conflicts, and poverty that remain pervasive across the planet.The astronaut Ron Garan called this the Orbital Perspective: “Seeing Earth from this vantage point gave me a unique perspective….Part of this is the realization that we are all traveling together on the planet and that if we all looked at the world from that perspective we would see that nothing is impossible.”
Find some quiet. Disconnect from the noise and reconnect with your core values, your purpose. Remember that we are but a blip on the timeline, but in this brief time we have on Earth, what can we do to contribute most to the society we wish for? I’m reminded of the line from a  Mary Oliver poem in which she asks, “Tell me, what is it you plan to do with your one wild and precious life?”
Redefine the Concept of Care.
 notion of self-care, similar to the idea of finding balance, has led to a lot of misconceptions about what is missing and what is needed. Care in the work of justice cannot be about transactional deeds (e.g. performative allyship) or superficial one-off practices (e.g. getting a massage, taking a weekend off). The burnout is real and severe and it’s killing us and our ability to engage in true transformative efforts for systemic change.
In the Four Pivots, Shawn Ginwright explores individual care (focused on concern for self), interpersonal care (awareness of how our well-being is interconnected), and institutional care (the social contract that assures the well-being of all).
For me, I’m taking some time to reflect on lessons I have learned from the past that can inform my long-term care practice.  That means detaching myself from 24/7 media, scheduling monthly “Yes Days” with each of my daughters, and getting back to the dance studio on a regular basis. But it’s also scheduling regular calls, coffee or lunch dates, and text chains with colleagues and friends so we can respond to one another’s needs. Community care is absolutely essential.
Unleash Our Wild Imagination
. Part of the success of the current systems of oppression is due to the deep fear we have to audaciously imagine alternatives to the status quo. 
From Shawn Gainwright: “...our inability to contemplate freedom and lean into a possible future is one of the most significant barriers we face in creating justice. Somewhere along the way we have learned to talk about problems, measure the problem, and finally define the misery that comes along with the problem itself.” 
“We can create a future we wish to see rather than simply eliminating the present conditions we need to change.” 
We need to remind ourselves and one another that our collective work is more than fighting against injustice…it’s about embracing the practice of dreaming and defining the future state we want and BELIEVING it is attainable. 
There have been and will continue to be moments in which I find myself overwhelmed, hopeless, enraged. I might have to reserve the right to take a beat so I can catch my breath and get myself back in the head and heart space to keep going. I know that when that happens, I can rely on my community to be TRU for me. And I offer the same to you. When you are feeling like you can’t take another step on this long road of social change, call on me. I’ll be TRU for you.
Maria Morukian
Founder and Chief Executive Officer
MSM Global Consulting
 
About MSM Global
We specialize in organizational culture change by empowering organizations to achieve greater success through embracing equity, diversity and inclusivity. We provide a holistic approach to organizational development, team capacity building, and leadership development. Let us know what would be helpful for you in this newsletter.

subject: Confronting Bias: How to Address Harmful Narratives in the Workplace
body:
Learn four different strategies to address harmful comments in the workplace in a productive manner. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Dear Tamara,
Imagine the following situation:
You’re standing by the coffee machine when your colleague, Mark, who you’ve known for years, approaches and starts chatting about the recent promotions.
Midway through the conversation, he makes an offhand remark: 
“I don’t think James deserved that promotion; he only got it because he’s Black.”
The statement lands with a jolt, leaving you momentarily stunned. James, a diligent team member known for his strategic thinking and dedication, is someone whose work has consistently contributed to the team's successes.
Your immediate reaction is a mix of surprise and disappointment. You know Mark as someone generally amicable and well-meaning, but this comment reveals an underlying bias that can’t be ignored.
This is a pivotal moment.
You recognize that how you respond could influence not only Mark's perspective but also contribute to shaping the broader work culture.
So, what would you say to Mark?
      
👉 
To learn four different ways you can react in a constructive manner, 
CLICK HERE
.
Bye for now!
Luiza

Hello Tamara!
Imagine this: A talented employee, Sarah, continually gets passed over for leadership projects despite her excellent performance.  
That is because her colleagues, unaware, are making decisions based on "gut feelings," selecting others they "click" with instead.  
What’s happening here is a classic case of unconscious bias—
often invisible, but it affects every organization.
 
Sarah’s experience is unfortunately common.  
Employees like her feel frustrated and undervalued, even though their contributions are just as significant.  
Over time, this leads to disengagement and can cause highly skilled individuals to leave. 
The problem is not that people consciously choose favorites.  
Rather, unconscious bias quietly shapes decisions, influencing who gets opportunities, promotions, or even who is seen as a good “cultural fit.” 
 
Without addressing unconscious bias, organizations miss out on harnessing the full potential of their workforce. 
Your organization, just like many others, is ready for a breakthrough—where employees don’t feel overlooked and everyone has an equal chance to contribute.  
The journey to a more inclusive future starts by confronting these biases head-on.
 
Priority action for you:
: Implement unconscious bias training for all employees to enhance awareness and provide your team with effective strategies to reduce its influence on everyday decision-making.
Bye for now!
Luiza
___________________________________
 
Luiza Dreasher, President and CEO (she/her/hers)
Mastering Cultural Differences 
I work with leaders who want to create a work environment where all employees feel valued and want to stay.

subject: Going Unnoticed: The Systematic Exclusion of Black Women over 35
body:
Groundbreaking new data from Included reveals a concerning trend: Black women over 35 experience significantly higher exclusion in the workplace
 
 
Dear colleagues,
As we celebrate Black History Month in the UK, it is vital to reflect not only on historical struggles but also on the ongoing, nuanced challenges of inclusion in the workplace.
Groundbreaking new data from 
Included
 reveals a concerning trend: Black women over 35 experience significantly higher exclusion across key dimensions of workplace experience. This finding has profound implications for organisations striving to create equitable environments.
Using data collected by 
Included
 from over 20,000 respondents spanning 40 countries, this analysis highlights the systematic disparities being faced by a specific group that organisations must address.  
We have asked each person multiple questions which allowed us to form a score for how included they felt across 7 categories:
  
Experiences of Microaggressions
 
Perceived Transparency & Objectivity in personnel decisions
 
Perceived Transparency & Objectivity in salary decisions
 
Perceived importance of ‘fitting in’
 
Psychological safety in teams 
 
Psychological safety with leaders
 
Perceived importance of diverse recruitment
What does the data tell us?
The data reveals a stark reality: Black women over 35 consistently score lower than other demographic groups across all 7 critical inclusion measures, including experiences of microaggressions, perceived transparency in decision-making, and psychological safety.
 
 
Scores of black women 35+ vs population average 
Other research, such as the 
2023 McKinsey report on workplace diversity
 and their 
2024 report on Women in the Workplace
, similarly highlighted the systemic challenges faced by Black women in leadership roles. The 
Race at Work
 report by Business in the Community
 also underscored how Black women are less likely to see career progression. This data adds to this research by quantitatively showing when this drop-off in inclusion is happening in Black women’s careers.
 
And this drop-off does seem to be happening around age 35, and specifically for Black women. When comparing to other racial groups and age groups, we see that this experience is unique to Black women over 35.
  
 
Scores of women with different races and ages 
Why is this happening?
 
Organisations often suggest they believe specifically Black women aren’t being included as much. But our data tells that this can also be specified by age.
 
There could be several reasons for this disparity, and certainly those reasons could vary by organisation. A positive spin on it may be that the newer generations are feeling more involved and less discriminated against as a result of generational progress of inclusivity. This has certainly been the case with some of our clients, where the focus on Black women’s inclusion has only begun recently and it’s taking time to shift both the experiences and opinions of longer-tenured employees.
 
However, a less positive explanation may be that young Black women come into the workforce hopeful of a more equitable culture than their elders experienced, but are having their hopes dashed by the time they are reaching the primes of their careers and seeing their progression stalled.
 
Sadly, other research seems to suggest the latter is more common. Research from 
Harvard Business Review
 indicates that women of color face greater challenges as they advance in their careers, including 
isolation, bias in promotion decisions
, and a 
lack of mentorship and sponsorship
.
 
By running the Inclusion Diagnostic, we have been able to quantitatively show how these specific issues – particularly the lack of access to and psychological safety with leaders – have been prohibiting the progression of Black women with some client organisations. And once highlighted, we’ve been able to 
implement programming to directly combat that exclusion
.
 
 
What can we do?
 
The case is clear, there are differences in the employee experience and indeed treatment, and Black women over 35 lose out. Here are 5 things you can do within your organisation to accelerate change:
 
Understand
 – where the barriers and opportunities are within your firm. Collect both inclusion AND equity data, and look at what the data tells you. Without it, you risk implementing interventions that don’t actually get to the heart of the issues in your organisation, making your EDI work less effective, less efficient, and less sustainable.
 
Review
 – your policies and procedures with an inclusion lens. We all have biases individually, but they’re much less likely to come into play when our policies and procedures account for them. If our policies and practice don’t mitigate our biases, they can have significant effects on our organisations, particularly when it comes to talent management. The stark number of organisations that have bias baked into their talent management processes is exceptionally high.
 
Sponsor
 – don’t just mentor. Sponsorship is much more active than mentorship. Sponsorship relationships are driven by the leader not just providing advice for their sponsees, but actually creating opportunities for their sponsees to advance their careers. Sponsors open up their networks, invest in their sponsees’ success, and are willing to fight for their sponsees.
 
Give feedback equitably
 – and notice who you’re giving feedback to. Most of us don’t realise that we tend to give more feedback (positive and constructive) to members of majority groups. Minoritised employees just tend to get less feedback overall. It’s so common an issue, it has its own name: The Thin File problem.
 
Map out
 – inclusive talent pathways for your organisation. By highlighting how minoritised individuals, especially Black women over 35, have attained leadership positions in your firm you show your employees that there really is a progression pathway.This should include sharing their full career paths, the barriers they faced at different stages, and how they overcame those barriers.
There’s obviously more that can and should be done, depending on points 1 and 2. For example, prioritising inclusive benefits, integrating inclusion as a leadership competency, etc; but hopefully this is a starting point to accelerating progress. 
At 
Included
, we specialise in actionable insights that drive organisational change. 
Contact us
 to learn how we can partner with your leadership team to create a more equitable future for all employees.
By valuing and supporting individuals, your organisation can better your people’s experiences at work and unlock the full potential of your workforce.
Full article located on our website 
here
.
 
The Race, Research & Policy Portal (RRAPP) 
  
The RRAPP is a free online resource to help organisational leaders, policymakers and educators achieve antiracist change. It features easily accessible research summaries on diversity, racial equity, and organisational change across sectors. Each summary focuses on antiracist solutions, listing clear takeaways in a short format. 
 
Explore the RRAPP
 
It’s ADHD Awareness Month!
  
We want to challenge our readers to move beyond awareness, and into action. So, what can you do?
If you’re a colleague or manager of someone with ADHD, you might be interested in learning about some key skills you can refine and build on in this article.
 
Read here
 
Find out more about 
Included
’s approach to diversity 
here
 and take a look at our 
Impact Report
. 
Please 
get in touch
 with us anytime to have a conversation about making your organisation more diverse and more inclusive.  We look forward to hearing from you. 
From all of us at 
Included

subject: Bringing an Intersectional Lens to Domestic Violence Awareness and Prevention
body:
“Rarely, if ever, are any of us healed in isolation. Healing is an act of communion.” – bell hooks
 
 
 
“Rarely, if ever, are any of us healed in isolation. Healing is an act of communion.” – bell hooks
October is Domestic Violence Awareness Month. The National Resource Center on Domestic Violence has introduced the theme of 
Heal, Hold, & Center 
to recognize and address the experiences of survivors from marginalized identities, stating: “As we heal, hold, and center survivors, especially those navigating anti-Blackness and other systems of oppression, we remain grounded in the knowledge that there is 
no survivor justice without racial justice
.” 
It is estimated that about 
1 in 2 women
 have experienced intimate partner violence in their lifetime, and 1 in 5 have experienced sexual violence by an intimate partner.  These numbers alone should be disturbing, and when we look at the racial, ethnic and cultural disparities that exist, it is even more appalling. According to the 
National Intimate Partner and Sexual Violence Survey
, women who identify as Black, Hispanic, American Indian or Alaska Native, and Multiracial experience IPV at far higher rates than White and Asian women. Members of the LGBTQ+ population also have higher rates of violence.  44% of lesbian women and 61% of bisexual women have experienced rape, physical violence, and/or stalking by an intimate partner in their lifetime. These disparities have been connected to issues of 
economic insecurity, combined with isolation, racism, and discrimination
, all which impact how women from minoritized identities experience and respond to domestic violence. Cultural or religious norms, fear or mistrust of law enforcement, lack of access to culturally or linguistically appropriate support services, all fear of immigration status all may contribute to women of the global majority getting the help they need and deserve. 
Fortunately, there is a more systemic effort being put into place to prevent and address domestic violence, with the focus being on collective work that brings allies, advocates, and survivors together to make change happen. As I’ve stated before, issues of gender inequality and violence are not a women’s issue. They are an everyone issue. 
For more information on what you can do to support change, check out the 
National Resource Center on Domestic Violence
, which has curated dozens of resources focusing on specific issues and identity group’s needs. 
Maria Morukian
Founder and Chief Executive Officer
MSM Global Consulting
MSM GLOBAL UPDATES
 
Ember 2024 is October 8th-10th in Denver, CO! - 
Fire Side Chat - A webinar on Ember
With generous support from our friends at the University of Colorado Denver, MSM Global and True Change Associates are leading the second annual EMBER convening, which brings together DEI professionals and social change agents to explore strategies for tackling complex systemic challenges and reignite their passion and energy. With insights from distinguished DEI leaders across various industries, we’ll explore strategies for overcoming institutional barriers and creating meaningful change together. 
DEI Ambassadors Take a Deep Dive into Exploring Systemic Racism
MSM Global Consulting’s DEI Ambassador Program is a comprehensive train-the-trainer DEI certificate program that equips individuals with the essential skills to lead impactful DEI dialogues and learning activities. 
Last month, we launched the exciting new Ambassador 2.0 pilot program, which builds on the foundation of our Ambassador Program. Ambassador 2.0 takes the DEI journey further by immersing participants in a nine-week cohort-based dialogue focused on race and racism in their respective fields. This next phase is fostering deeper reflection and action in advancing DEI efforts.
Learn more about the Ambassador program 
here
, and contact us if you would like to run this dynamic program with your organization! 
  
Culture Stew
We’ve hit 100 Episodes! 
In the first episode of Season 6, we're celebrating our 100th episode of Culture Stew. Join Maria Morukian as she talks with scholars Devin Moran and Jasmin Robinson to discuss the challenges Black women leaders face and how to balance justice work with self-care. Listen now to this powerful conversation on intersectional gender equity on your favorite podcast platform or the 
MSM Global Consulting website
! 
 
MSM GLOBAL GALLERY
Here you can find curated content of current DEI issues and events for your further exploration.
 
Honoring Indigenous Peoples' Day: Going Beyond Land Acknowledgement 
This Indigenous Peoples' Day takes place October 14. A common practice that has gained steam in recent years is land acknowledgement. Land acknowledgement is an attempt to recognize the Indigenous nations upon whose land an entity may occupy, and is often offered either in written or verbal form. Although land acknowledgement may be delivered with positive intent, it can also be seen as performative and can frustrate members of Indigenous communities who may be called upon to engage in the emotional labor of offering guidance and advice on such acknowledgements.  It also begs the question, what are we actively doing to recognize and respond to the actual needs of Indigenous communities who have experienced intergenerational violence and oppression throughout the history of our nation? 
The 
Native Governance Center
 offers tips for ways to go beyond land acknowledgement to engage in true advocacy for Indigenous populations. In addition to encouraging people to do their own research on the history of the Indigenous land they occupy, the Center encourages individuals and organizations to assess how they might use their resources to support Indigenous communities in terms of money, time, land/space, tuition or entry into events or activities that provide value for those communities. Discover more guidance 
here
.
A Proclamation on National Domestic Violence Awareness and Prevention Month
The White House
 
October is National Domestic Violence Awareness and Prevention Month, and this year we also commemorate the 30th anniversary of the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA). We encourage leaders and advocates for social change to raise awareness about the prevalence of domestic violence and to take action in supporting survivors and preventing abuse. Domestic violence impacts millions of individuals across all backgrounds, and it is our collective responsibility to foster safe and supportive environments where everyone can live free from violence and fear.
If you or someone you know is experiencing domestic violence, there are resources available to help: 
National Domestic Violence Hotline: Call 1-800-799-SAFE (7233), text "START" to 88788, or visit 
thehotline.org
 for confidential support.
RAINN (Rape, Abuse & Incest National Network): Call 1-800-656-HOPE (4673) or visit 
rainn.org
 for help and resources.
Local Shelters and Support Services: Visit 
domesticshelters.org
 to find nearby shelters and services.
Learn more about this important month and how you can take action by reading 
the official proclamation.
 
We're waiting for you! 
Would you like to be a guest on the Culture Stew Podcast? 
Do you have a publication we can share on our newsletter or on our social media accounts? 
 
Contact us at 
CultureStew
@MSMGlobalConsulting.com
 TODAY! 
CONTENT FOR YOUR DOWN TIME
Here are some recommended articles and books for your down time.
 
Celebrating Artistic Powerhouses: Natalia Hernandez, Carolyn Castaño, and Carmen Linares 
In celebration of Hispanic Heritage Month, we highlight three remarkable women shaping the landscape of art, literature, and music. From Natalia Hernandez’s queer fantasy novels set in Latin American-inspired worlds, to Carolyn Castaño’s award-winning mixed-media artistry, and Carmen Linares’ legendary flamenco performances, these Hispanic creators are leaving an indelible mark on contemporary culture while proudly representing their heritage.
 
Natalia Hernandez
 -Author - Natalia Hernandez is the author of acclaimed fantasy book, The Name Bearer, is described as “a story of magia, warrior women, found family and love - and not accepting who you are told to be, but embracing who you are destined to become.” Hernandez identifies as an Indigenous, Latinx, queer book nerd, and Third Culture Kid who has lived all over the globe.  Her work centers queer identities and strong women of color, and Latin American culture.
 
 
Carolyn Castaño
 -Artist -Carolyn Castaño is a Los Angeles-based artist whose work spans painting, drawing, video, and mixed-media installations. A recipient of prestigious awards like the Joan Mitchell Foundation Grant and the California Community Foundation Getty Fellow Grant, her work has been showcased in notable exhibitions, including the Venice Biennale and LACMA. Currently, she is an Assistant Professor of Painting and Drawing at Long Beach City College.
 
Carmen Linares
 - Musician - Carmen Linares, a living legend of 
flamenco
, has earned a prominent place in Spanish musical culture, alongside icons like Tomatito and Paco de Lucía. With a career spanning over 40 years, Linares has performed internationally and collaborated with renowned artists. Her discography includes over 30 titles, and she recently celebrated her milestone project, Cantaora: 40 years of flamenco. Linares' achievements have been recognized with numerous awards, including the 2022 Princess of Asturias Award and the 2023 Latin Grammy Award.

subject: Are you ready for the changes to the Worker’s Protection Act?
body:
Employers will have additional responsibility to take “reasonable steps” to prevent sexual harassment in the workplace from 26th October.
 
 
Dear colleagues,
Employers will have additional responsibility to take “reasonable steps” to prevent sexual harassment in the workplace from 26
th
 October. This includes engaging in training, process and policy reviews, third-party facing mechanisms, and appropriate reporting processes.
 
Failing to actively prevent sexual harassment in the workplace will result in a 25% increased financial compensation for victims in cases taken to Employment Tribunal.
  
Why is this sexual harassment in the workplace a timely topic?
I’m sure we can all agree that sexual harassment has no place in life full stop, let alone in the workplace.
But it happens. Far too often.
 
A 
new report by McKinsey and LeanIn
 shows that sexual harassment is just as prevalent now, in 2024, than in 2018.
 
In 2018, 35 percent of women reported experiencing at least one form of 
sexual harassment 
in the workplace, according to the report, published this week. This year, that portion is 37 percent. Of course, people of all genders experience sexual harassment, and the 
changes to the Worker’s Protection Act
 (WPA) equally covers all people regardless of gender.
We can also guarantee that there are far more experiences of sexual harassment than those we see through these statistics. A lack of psychological safety to speak out, a lack of understanding of what constitutes sexual harassment, and internalised guilt all affect reporting rates and should be taken seriously.
Our work shows consistently that any workplace inclusion issue such as micro aggressions, pay inequality, or in this case, sexual harassment, tends to happen more frequently to people in minoritised groups.
  
So what should you do?
 
As employers, leaders, and practitioners it is important that you prepare for the changes to the WPA, and fulfil the responsibility to take ‘reasonable steps’ to prevent sexual harassment.
Here are 5 recommendations to get you started:
 
Understand: 
Run psychologically safe focus groups and interviews to learn more about employees’ experiences to inform approaches. Whether traditional focus groups or anonymised digital ones, listening to your colleagues is important and imperative.
 
Raise awareness:
 Run sessions on the topic to raise colleague awareness of what sexual harassment is, and the governance and support available. A participant at one of our recent Anti-Sexual Harassment webinars said, "
The managing directors contacted me after 5 mins of the session to tell me they were not expecting such a high quality of materials and delivery from the facilitators. TOP NOTCH!" 
 
Strengthen governance:
 review, update and improve existing policies on sexual harassment (and surrounding policies on bullying and harassment, ethics and employee conduct); taking into account the understanding and application of policies. For example you may want to train a team of ambassadors or support staff to become points of contact on the topic of sexual harassment in the workplace
 
Take the 
right
 action:
 Work with and lead steering groups or committees to tailor a bespoke response to the WPA changes; complete with an action plan and RACI models
 
Align outcomes:
 organisations that link values and behaviours to their performance management outcomes, see quicker results and culture change. Besides policy change, consider the range of implications (whether that be pay related, training, through to termination) that can and should be taken and the rigor that governs this.
Get in touch
 to learn more, we’d love to support you in implementing responses to the upcoming changes and increased responsibilities you hold in your workplaces. Clients have described our work in this space as “thought-provoking”, “effective”, “powerful”, and “empowering”. We bring expertise, experience, and openness to create spaces for meaningful dialogue, concrete plans, and reassurance for colleagues and key stakeholders alike.
If you have a story to share please get in touch via email at 
info@included.com
. By valuing and supporting individuals, your organisation can better your people’s experiences at work and unlock the full potential of your workforce.

Join 
Included
 and Fair Pay Innovation Lab for this insightful session exploring how you can move beyond pay equity to create truly inclusive workplaces.
The session wraps up with a Q&A where you can raise questions and share challenges. If time permits, optional Breakout Discussions will explore topics like measuring EDI impact, inclusive leadership, and actionable ways to integrate inclusion into everyday work.
